title: Configure values.yaml for Audit
content:
You need to create a custom values.yaml file and configure the parameters for an Audit deployment.

Create and configure values.yaml file

You can create and configure the values.yaml file based on the sample file (Example values.yaml) provided in the Audit charts package.

  1. Create a copy of the sample file in the Install directory, for example, audit20xx.xx.

    cp audit-helm-chart/audit/samples/values.yaml .

  2. Edit the values.yaml file using any editor and give the required values in the file.

Configurable parameters

The values.yaml file contains configurable parameters that are categorized into the following two types:

  • Global parameters: These parameters help define a setting that affects all deployed services. These parameters reside under the global helm key index. For example, global.idm. idmSvcHost.
  • Component specific parameters: These are parameters that target a specified component/sub-chart. In the values.yaml file, you can find these parameters under the block of values whose name corresponds to the sub-chart/component name. 
    For example, 
    auditService:
database:

Access parameters

Parameters for audit service access
Parameter Description Required Default Example
global.externalAccessHost This is the FQDN you will use for external access to Audit service. Yes Not defined smax.example.com
global.externalAccessPort

This is the port you will use for external access to Audit service.

 Yes Not defined 9889
global.nginx.httpsPort This is the listener port of the NGINX controller service. Yes same as global.externalAccessPort 9889
global.securityContext.user

This parameter specifies the operating system user ID that is used to run the process in the container.

The value of this parameter and the ID of the NFS folder owner (the value of <user> when creating the Audit NFS volumes) must be the same. For example, if you use 100001 instead of 1999 when creating NFS, you must also use 100001 as the value for this parameter. 

NOTE: The value can't be changed after installation.

Yes

 1999 100001
global.securityContext.fsGroup

This parameter specifies the operating system group ID that is used to run the process in the container.

The value of this parameter and the group ID (the value of <fsGroup> when creating the Audit NFS volumes) must be the same. For example, if you use 200001 instead of 1999 when creating NFS, you must also use 200001 as the value for this parameter. 

NOTE: The value can't be changed after installation.

Yes

 1999 200001

Docker registry settings

parameters for docker registry
Parameter Description Required Default Example
global.docker.registry The docker registry from where the required images will get pulled from. Yes localhost:5000 smax.docker.registry:5000
global.docker.orgName The docker organization name. Yes hpeswitom hpeswitom
global.docker.imagePullSecret The K8s secret that contains the credentials required to pull images from the specified docker registry. Yes registrypullsecret registrypullsecret
global.docker.imagePullPolicy The image pull policy. Optional IfNotPresent IfNotPresent

External IdM configuration

Only https is supported for IdM communication

Parameters for IdM access
Parameter Description Required Default Example
global.idm.idmSvcHost The FQDN to access IdM. It's usually same as the Service Management FQDN. Yes Not defined smax.example.com
global.idm.idmSvcPort The external port to access IdM. It's usually same as the Service Management port. Yes 443 443

Vault init configuration

parameters for vault init
Parameter Description Required Default Example
global.vaultInit.certname The name used to generate a certificate within the vault init. Yes Not defined smax.example.com

TLS configuration 

parameters for TLS settings
Parameter Description Required Default Example
global.tls.tlsMinVersion Define the minimum TLS version. Leave these fields empty if you want to use the default values. The tlsMinVersion parameter value must be in this format: "TLSv1.x" (possible values: TLSv1.2 / TLSv1.3) Optional TLSv1.2 TLSv1.2
global.tls.tlsCiphers Define a list of comma separated ciphers. Leave these fields empty if you want to use the default values. The tlsCipher parameter value must be in this format: [ "cipher1","cipher2" ] Optional TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,
TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,
TLS_AES_128_CCM_8_SHA256,
TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256		 TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,
TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

Core audit service configuration

Audit service picks up the hostname and port for IdM in the following order: 

  1. auditService.idm.internalIdmHost and auditService.idm.internalIdmPort values (this is strongly recommended).
  2. When you don't specify auditService.idm.internalIdmHost and auditService.idm.internalIdmPort values, Audit service picks up auditService.idm.publicIdmHost and auditService.idm.publicIdmPort values.
  3. When you don't specify auditService.idm.publicIdmHost and auditService.idm.publicIdmPort values, then Audit service picks up the global.idm.idmSvcHost and global.idm.idmSvcPort values.
parameters for audit service
Parameter Description Required Default Example
auditService.replicas The number of Audit service pods that need to be running. No 2 2
auditService.database.user The external DB user. Yes Not defined auditdbuser
auditService.database.jdbcUrl The external DB database JDBC URL. Yes Not defined jdbc:postgresql://auditdb.example.com:5432/audit?ssl=true&sslmode=verify-ca&sslfactory=org.postgresql.ssl.DefaultJavaSSLFactory
auditService.hpa.maxReplicas Maximum number of pods for Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) to trigger. Optional 2 2
auditService.hpa.minReplicas Minimum number of pods for HPA to trigger. Optional 2 2
auditService.hpa.targetCPUUtilizationPercentage Threshold percentage for HPA. Optional 75 75
auditService.idm.publicIdmHost This is the hostname that's used to access the IdM service externally.  Optional Not defined smax.example.com
auditService.idm.publicIdmPort This is the port that's used to access the IdM service externally.  Optional 443 443
auditService.idm.internalIdmHost This is the hostname used to access the IdM service that's internal to the Service Management deployment. This hostname isn't exposed externally. Optional Not defined int.smax.example.com
auditService.idm.internalIdmPort This is the port that's used to access the IdM service that's internal to the Service Management deployment. This port isn't exposed externally. Optional 443 443
auditService.jmx.enable  Enables JMX support for Audit service. Use this only in the debugging mode. Optional false false

IdM user configuration

parameters for IdM user settings
Parameter Description Required Default Example
auditService.idm.superUser The user that's used to call IdM APIs to create the required groups, roles, and permissions. The user in IdM has to have the admin/super user privilege. Yes Not defined suite-admin
auditService.idm.superUserOrgName The super user organization. Yes Not defined sysbo

Audit gateway configuration

parameters for audit gateway
Parameter Description Required Default Example
auditGateway.deployment.publicIdmHost This is the hostname that's used to access the IdM service externally. If the value isn't specified, then Audit gateway will take the FQDN from global.idm.idmSvcHost. Optional Not defined smax.example.com
auditGateway.deployment.publicIdmPort This is the port that's used to access the IdM service externally. If the value isn't specified, then Audit gateway will take the value from global.idm.idmSvcPort. Optional 443 443
auditGateway.deployment.internalIdmHost This is the hostname that's used to access the IdM service that's internal to the Service Management deployment. This hostname isn't exposed externally. If the value isn't specified, then Audit gateway will take the FQDN from global.idm.idmSvcHost. Optional Not defined int.smax.example.com
auditGateway.deployment.internalIdmPort This is the port that's used to access the IdM service that's internal to the Service Management deployment. This port isn't exposed externally. If the value isn't specified, then Audit gateway will take the value from global.idm.idmSvcPort. Optional 443 443
auditGateway.deployment.idmTransportUser The IdM transport username. Optional idmTransportUser idmTransportUser
auditGateway.deployment.auditEndPoint The Audit service end point. Recommended https://<global.externalAccessHost>:<global.externalAccessPort>/audit-service-engine https://audit.example.com:9889/audit-service-engine
auditGateway.hpa.maxReplicas Maximum number of pods for HPA to trigger. Optional 2 2
auditGateway.hpa.minReplicas Minimum number of pods for HPA to trigger. Optional 2 2
auditGateway.hpa.targetCPUUtilizationPercentage Threshold percentage for HPA. Optional 75 75
auditGateway.jmx.enable Enables JMX support for Audit gateway. Use this only in the debugging mode. Optional  false false
auditGateway.logging.level.root Use this to set the log level for root. For example, info, debug, and error. Optional info info
auditGateway.logging.level.com.microfocus.itom.audit Use this to set the log level for the Audit gateway code. For example, info, debug, and error. Optional info info

Specify custom certificate(s) for Audit to use

This is an optional step for configuring Audit to use custom certificates.

parameters for custom certificates
Parameter Description Required Default Example
global.tls.cert The .pem encoded content of the custom certificate(s). No Not defined "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIFGzCCBAOgAwIBAgITfAAAA2iVjHu0vPAXsAAEAAADaDANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsF
[...]
JJ1hTIEoy96UnOIt5gQL
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIDfDCCAmSgAwIBAgIQOTQW1b748rlAtafk4cM8nDANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFADA9
[...]
utV0Pu/h9fsOEFaUiA9cWMGzH2p4aKNEIIAg67NxmQM=
-----END CERTIFICATE-----"
global.tls.key

The .pem encoded content of the key.

 No Not defined

"-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
MIIEpAIBAAKCAQEAoR9CY4dwTMU+BKWwRsX+cpIFahRDN091Pc7qL4uMwEfi+W6r
[...]
//uHRFpE0FUvgFo8bV+rBzsQc5EMYB7udoYPRP2cSH3ly64OLE0T9A==
-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----"

If you are using a Load Balancer for the suite or Audit, then this step isn't required, because you can configure the custom certificates in the Load Balancer itself.

If you aren't using a Load Balancer, by default Audit uses a self-signed certificate with the Nginx ingress controller deployed at install time. This certificate gets generated by Audit deployed vault component.

The custom certificate you plan to use with Audit is installed in the Audit deployed Nginx ingress controller and not in the individual Audit components.

If you are using a custom certificate with the suite, you can use the same one for Audit.

To specify a custom certificate for Audit:

  1. Have the custom certificate(s) you want to use with Audit in a .pem format (base64 encoded).
  2. Upload the custom certificate(s) and key to a directory on the control plane node.
  3. Open values.yaml in a text editor
  4. Search for Helm parameters global and then introduce tls and under it cert (global.tls.cert) and key (global.tls.key) tags as shown below
  5. Set the certificate(s) content at Helm parameter global.tls.cert and the content of the key at Helm parameter global.tls.key.

  6. If a multiple level certificate authority has signed the certificate, concatenate the certificate in the following order: 

    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<server-certificate>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<intermediate-level-1>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<intermediate-level-2>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<intermediate-level-n>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
<root.crt>
-----END CERTIFICATE-----

    Make sure that there are no empty lines between certificates

  7. You must include the content of the certificate(s) and key in double quotes. For example:

  8. During Audit Helm installation, give the CA certificate used to sign the custom certificate using the following command:

    $helm install <Audit Release Name> <Audit Service Chart> -n <Audit Namespace> -f values.yaml -f <Secrets YAML File> --set-file "caCertificates.cert_one\.crt"=/path/to/cert_one.crt --set-file "caCertificates.cert_two\.crt"=/path/to/cert_two.crt --set-file "caCertificates.RE_ca_custcrt"=/path/to/customCA.crt
